title: LR circuit - currents after a long time

content.question: A circuit containing an inductor of inductance <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, resistors <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>1</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> of resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> and <math alttext="2 R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi></math>, respectively, a battery of <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="open E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>∆ê</mi></math>, two ammeters, and a switch is constructed as shown in the diagram. After the switch is closed and the circuit reaches steady state, how does the current <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> measured by Ammeter <math alttext="A sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>1</mtext></msub></math> compare to the current <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> measured by Ammeter <math alttext="A sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>A</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and why?

choices.label: <math alttext="I sub 1 equals I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, because the two branches in parallel have the same potential difference.

<math alttext="I sub 1 equals I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, because the inductor and Resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math> have the same resistance.

<math alttext="I sub 1 is less than I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, because the inductor will behave as a conducting wire with zero resistance.

<math alttext="I sub 1 is less than I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, because there is a greater potential difference across the inductor than Resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="I sub 1 is less than I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, because the inductor will behave as a conducting wire with zero resistance.
